to act this way because your grandfather
is the president well Jason was our

we don't need another car burning in the

President Carter is still active here in
his hometown of Plains where he
occasionally teaches Sunday school at
the Maranatha Baptist Church amidst the
town that has been preserved in his
honor in many ways just as it was before
he was president but even in this bubble
and even among Carter family friends
like Jan Williams who taught Amy Carter
in grade school and introduces the
president at church there is an
awareness that the current political
climate is complicated Jason is his own
man but he does talk with his
grandfather and I think he has a lot of
his grandfather's traits I think he's
got it in a lot of ways I like going for
him by being the grandson of President
Carter but then he also has to take it
easy sometimes especially if people did
not vote for Jimmy Carter or if they did
not really like him as a president that
can hurt him so he's kind of got to keep
it in the middle of the road Georgia is
next in line is a battleground state
here and people may agree or disagree
about whether it's red or blue but
everybody agrees that it's changing
today more than half of all newly
registered Georgia voters are non-white
they're mostly black and mostly voting
for Democrats overall the percentage of
white registered voters in Georgia
has dropped from 72% in 2000 to 59%
today and while Mitt Romney did win
Georgia in the 2012 presidential race he
did so by a slim margin that appears to
be shrinking even more President Carter
maintains a 61 percent approval rating
in the state well sometimes I give him
advice but it's kind of reluctant advice
because I know that circumstances in
Georgia are quite different from what I
knew when I ran for it was elected
governor in 1970 at the end of the day
it's my campaign and
he knows that and he he respects that he
doesn't get told no by very many other
people in the world and that may be why
one of the reasons why we're as close as
we are there was one major meeting and
Albany Georgia and I offered to go down
and be with Jason that at his rally
there and after careful and I think
appropriate consideration he has that I
not go because he wanted to the people
in Southwest Georgia to see that he was
a man of his own and he didn't want the
attention to be focused on me and Rosa
while President Carter maintains a
distance from some events he is heavily
invested in his grandsons campaign if he
got elected governor of Georgia by
shaking six hundred thousand hands you
know that's what he would tell you you
know you got to go to the grocery store
and and shake everybody's name and I
wish you know politics was still like
that you know and I wish that that was
sort of the the modern way of doing
things I think the way that he lives and
the way that he has influenced me the
most is to say that politics cannot come
first because there's things that are
more important than being a winning
politician
well I failed the first time I ran as
